entry.name: undelegate
entry.desc: Remove a handler from the event for all elements which match the current selector, now or in the future, based upon a specific set of root elements.

argument.name: selector
argument.desc: A selector which will be used to filter the event results.

argument.name: eventType
argument.desc: A string containing a JavaScript event type, such as "click" or "keydown"

argument.name: selector
argument.desc: A selector which will be used to filter the event results.

argument.name: eventType
argument.desc: A string containing a JavaScript event type, such as "click" or "keydown"

argument.name: handler
argument.desc: A function to execute at the time the event is triggered.

longdesc.p: Undelegate is a way of removing event handlers that have been bound using .delegate(). It works virtually identically to .die() with the addition of a selector filter argument (which is required for delegation to work).

example.desc: Can bind and unbind events to the colored button.
example.css: button { margin:5px; } button#theone { color:red; background:yellow; }
example.html: Click!

example.desc: To unbind all delegated events from all paragraphs, write:
To unbind all delegated click events from all paragraphs, write:
To undelegate just one previously bound handler, pass the function in as the third argument:

entry.name: delegate
entry.desc: Attach a handler to the event for all elements which match the current selector, now or in the future, based upon a specific set of root elements.

argument.name: selector
argument.desc: A selector to filter the elements that trigger the event.

argument.name: eventType
argument.desc: A string containing one or more space-separated JavaScript event types, such as "click" or "keydown," or custom event names.

argument.name: handler
argument.desc: A function to execute at the time the event is triggered.

argument.name: selector
argument.desc: A selector to filter the elements that trigger the event.

argument.name: eventType
argument.desc: A string containing one or more space-separated JavaScript event types, such as "click" or "keydown," or custom event names.

argument.name: eventData
argument.desc: A map of data that will be passed to the event handler.

argument.name: handler
argument.desc: A function to execute at the time the event is triggered.

longdesc.p: Delegate is an alternative to using the .live() method, allowing for each binding of event delegation to specific DOM elements. For example the following delegate code:
Is equivalent to the following code written using .live():
See also the .undelegate() method for a way of removing event handlers added in .delegate().

example.desc: Click a paragraph to add another. Note that .delegate() binds the click event to all paragraphs - even new ones.
To display each paragraph's text in an alert box whenever it is clicked:
To cancel a default action and prevent it from bubbling up, return false:
To cancel only the default action by using the preventDefault method.
Can bind custom events too.
example.css: p { color:red; } span { color:blue; }
example.html: Has an attached custom event.

entry.name: jQuery.error

argument.name: message
argument.desc: The message to send out.

entry.desc: Takes a string and throws an exception containing it.

longdesc.p: This method exists primarily for plugin developers who wish to override it and provide a better display (or more information) for the error messages.

example.desc: Override jQuery.error for display in Firebug.

entry.name: jQuery.parseJSON

argument.name: json
argument.desc: The JSON string to parse.

entry.desc: Takes a well-formed JSON string and returns the resulting JavaScript object.

longdesc.p: Passing in a malformed JSON string will result in an exception being thrown. For example, the following are all malformed JSON strings:

ul.li: {test: 1} (test does not have double quotes around it).
{'test': 1} ('test' is using single quotes instead of double quotes).

longdesc.p: Additionally if you pass in nothing, an empty string, null, or undefined, 'null' will be returned from parseJSON.

example.desc: Parse a JSON string.

entry.name: jQuery.proxy

argument.name: function
argument.desc: The function whose context will be changed.

argument.name: context
argument.desc: The object to which the context (`this`) of the function should be set.

argument.name: context
argument.desc: The object to which the context of the function should be set.

argument.name: name
argument.desc: The name of the function whose context will be changed (should be a property of the 'context' object.

entry.desc: Takes a function and returns a new one that will always have a particular context.

longdesc.p: This method is most useful for attaching event handlers to an element where the context is pointing back to a different object. Additionally, jQuery makes sure that even if you bind the function returned from jQuery.proxy() it will still unbind the correct function, if passed the original.

example.desc: Enforce the context of the function.

entry.name: focusout
entry.desc: Bind an event handler to the "focusout" JavaScript event.

argument.name: handler(eventObject)
argument.desc: A function to execute each time the event is triggered.

longdesc.p: This method is a shortcut for .bind('focusout', handler).

The focusout event is sent to an element when it, or any element inside of it, loses focus. This is distinct from the blur event in that it supports detecting the loss of focus from parent elements (in other words, it supports events bubbling).
This event will likely be used together with the focusin event.

example.desc: Watch for a loss of focus to occur within the paragraphs on the page.
example.css: span {display:none;}

entry.name: focusin
entry.desc: Bind an event handler to the "focusin" JavaScript event.

argument.name: handler(eventObject)
argument.desc: A function to execute each time the event is triggered.

longdesc.p: This method is a shortcut for .bind('focusin', handler).
The focusin event is sent to an element when it, or any element inside of it, gains focus. This is distinct from the focus event in that it supports detecting the focus event on parent elements.
This event will likely be used together with the focusout event.

example.desc: Watch for a focus to occur within the paragraphs on the page.
example.css: span {display:none;}

entry.name: has

argument.name: selector
argument.desc: A string containing a selector expression to match elements against.

argument.name: contained
argument.desc: A DOM element to match elements against.

entry.desc: Reduce the set of matched elements to those that have a descendant that matches the selector or DOM element.

longdesc.p: Given a jQuery object that represents a set of DOM elements, the .has() method constructs a new jQuery object from a subset of the matching elements. The supplied selector is tested against the descendants of the matching elements; the element will be included in the result if any of its descendant elements matches the selector.
Consider a page with a nested list as follows:
longdesc.pre:
• list item 1
  • list item 2
    • list item 2-a
    • list item 2-b
  • list item 3
  • list item 4
longdesc.p: We can apply this method to the set of list items as follows:
The result of this call is a red background for item 2, as it is the only <li> that has a <ul> among its descendants.

example.desc: Check if an element is inside another.
example.css: .full { border: 1px solid red; }

entry.name: jQuery.contains

argument.name: container
argument.desc: The DOM element that may contain the other element.

argument.name: contained
argument.desc: The DOM node that may be contained by the other element.

entry.desc: Check to see if a DOM node is within another DOM node.

example.desc: Check if an element is inside another.
example.code: jQuery.contains(document.documentElement, document.body); // true jQuery.contains(document.body, document.documentElement); // false

entry.name: jQuery.noop
entry.desc: An empty function.

longdesc.p: You can use this empty function when you wish to pass around a function that will do nothing.
This is useful for plugin authors who offer optional callbacks; in the case that no callback is given, something like jQuery.noop could execute.

entry.name: delay

argument.name: duration
argument.desc: An integer indicating the number of milliseconds to delay execution of the next item in the queue.

argument.name: queueName
argument.desc: A string containing the name of the queue. Defaults to fx, the standard effects queue.

entry.desc: Set a timer to delay execution of subsequent items in the queue.

longdesc.p: Added to jQuery in version 1.4, the .delay() method allows us to delay the execution of functions that follow it in the queue. It can be used with the standard effects queue or with a custom queue.

Durations are given in milliseconds; higher values indicate slower animations, not faster ones. The strings 'fast' and 'slow' can be supplied to indicate durations of 200 and 600 milliseconds, respectively.
Using the standard effects queue, we can, for example, set an 800-millisecond delay between the .slideUp() and .fadeIn() of <div id="foo">:
When this statement is executed, the element slides up for 300 milliseconds and then pauses for 800 milliseconds before fading in for 400 milliseconds.

example.desc: Animate the hiding and showing of two divs, delaying the first before showing it.

entry.name: parentsUntil

argument.name: selector
argument.desc: A string containing a selector expression to indicate where to stop matching ancestor elements.

entry.desc: Get the ancestors of each element in the current set of matched elements, up to but not including the element matched by the selector.

longdesc.p: Given a jQuery object that represents a set of DOM elements, the .parentsUntil() method traverses through the ancestors of these elements until it reaches an element matched by the selector passed in the method's argument. The resulting jQuery object contains all of the ancestors up to but not including the one matched by the .parentsUntil() selector. Consider a page with a basic nested list as follows:
longdesc.pre:
• I
  • II
    • A
    • B
      • 1
      • 2
      • 3
    • C
  • III
longdesc.p: If we begin at item A, we can find its ancestors up to but not including <ul class="level-1"> as follows:
The result of this call is a red background for the level-2 list and the item II.

If the .parentsUntil() selector is not matched, or if no selector is supplied, the returned jQuery object contains all of the previous jQuery object's ancestors. For example, let's say we begin at item A again, but this time we use a selector that is not matched by any of its ancestors:
The result of this call is a red background-color style applied to the level-2 list, the item II, the level-1 list, the <body> element, and the <html> element.

example.desc: Find the ancestors of <li class="item-a"> up to <ul class="level-1"> and give them a red background color.
example.html:
• I
  • II
    • A
    • B
      • 1
      • 2
      • 3
    • C
  • III

entry.name: prevUntil

argument.name: selector
argument.desc: A string containing a selector expression to indicate where to stop matching preceding sibling elements.

entry.desc: Get all preceding siblings of each element up to but not including the element matched by the selector.

longdesc.p: Given a jQuery object that represents a set of DOM elements, the .prevUntil() method allows us to search through the predecessors of these elements in the DOM tree, stopping when it reaches an element matched by the method's argument. The new jQuery object that is returned contains all previous siblings up to but not including the one matched by the .prevUntil() selector.

If the selector is not matched or is not supplied, all previous siblings will be selected; in these cases it selects the same elements as the .prevAll() method does when no filter selector is provided.
Consider a page with a simple definition list as follows:
If we begin at the second term, we can find the elements which come after it until a preceding <dt>.
The result of this call is a red background behind definitions 1-a, 1-b, 1-c, and 1-d.

example.desc: Find the siblings that precede <dt id="term-2"> up to the preceding <dt> and give them a red background color.

entry.name: nextUntil

argument.name: selector
argument.desc: A string containing a selector expression to indicate where to stop matching following sibling elements.

entry.desc: Get all following siblings of each element up to but not including the element matched by the selector.

longdesc.p: Given a jQuery object that represents a set of DOM elements, the .nextUntil() method allows us to search through the successors of these elements in the DOM tree, stopping when it reaches an element matched by the method's argument. The new jQuery object that is returned contains all following siblings up to but not including the one matched by the .nextUntil() selector.

If the selector is not matched or is not supplied, all following siblings will be selected; in these cases it selects the same elements as the .nextAll() method does when no filter selector is provided.
Consider a page with a simple definition list as follows:
If we begin at the second term, we can find the elements which come after it until a following <dt>.
The result of this call is a red background behind definitions 2-a, 2-b, and 2-c.

example.desc: Find the siblings that follow <dt id="term-2"> up to the next <dt> and give them a red background color.

entry.name: event.isImmediatePropagationStopped
entry.desc: Returns whether event.stopImmediatePropagation() was ever called on this event object.

longdesc.p: This property was introduced in DOM level 3.

example.desc: Checks whether event.stopImmediatePropagation() was called.

entry.name: event.stopImmediatePropagation
entry.desc: Keeps the rest of the handlers from being executed.

longdesc.p: This method also stops the bubbling by implicitly calling event.stopPropagation(). Use event.isImmediatePropagationStopped() to know whether this method was ever called (on that event object).

example.desc: Prevents other event handlers from being called.
example.css: p { height: 30px; width: 150px; background-color: #ccf; } div {height: 30px; width: 150px; background-color: #cfc; }

entry.name: event.isPropagationStopped
entry.desc: Returns whether event.stopPropagation() was ever called on this event object.

example.desc: Checks whether event.stopPropagation() was called

entry.name: event.stopPropagation
entry.desc: This method prevents the event from bubbling up the DOM tree, preventing any parent handlers from being notified of the event.

longdesc.p: We can use .isPropagationStopped() to determine if this method has been called by an event handler that was triggered by this event.
This method works for custom events triggered with trigger(), as well.
Note that this will not prevent other handlers on the same element from running. Use the method event.isPropagationStopped() to know whether this method was ever called (on that event object).

example.desc: Kill the bubbling on the click event.

entry.name: event.isDefaultPrevented
entry.desc: Returns whether event.preventDefault() was ever called on this event object.

example.desc: Checks whether event.preventDefault() was called.

entry.name: event.preventDefault
entry.desc: If this method is called, the default action of the event will not be triggered.

longdesc.p: For example, clicked anchors will not take the browser to a new URL. We can use event.isDefaultPrevented() to determine if this method has been called by an event handler that was triggered by this event.

example.desc: Cancel the default action (navigation) of the click.
example.html: default click action is prevented

entry.name: event.timeStamp
entry.desc: This attribute returns the number of milliseconds since January 1, 1970, when the event is triggered.
entry.longdesc: It can be useful for profiling the performance of certain jQuery functions.

example.desc: Alert the time since click handler last executed.

entry.name: event.result
entry.desc: This attribute contains the last value returned by an event handler that was triggered by this event, unless the value was undefined.
entry.longdesc: It can be useful for getting previous return values of custom events.

example.desc: Alert previous handler's return value

entry.name: event.which
entry.desc: For key or button events, this attribute indicates the specific button or key that was pressed.

longdesc.p: event.which normalizes event.keyCode and event.charCode. It is recommended to watch event.which for keyboard key input. For more detail, read about event.charCode on the MDC.

example.desc: Log what key was depressed.

entry.name: event.pageY
entry.desc: The mouse position relative to the top edge of the document.

example.desc: Show the mouse position relative to the left and top edges of the document (within this iframe).
example.css: body {background-color: #eef; } div { padding: 20px; }

entry.name: event.pageX
entry.desc: The mouse position relative to the left edge of the document.

example.desc: Show the mouse position relative to the left and top edges of the document (within the iframe).
example.css: body {background-color: #eef; } div { padding: 20px; }

entry.name: event.currentTarget
entry.desc: The current DOM element within the event bubbling phase.

longdesc.p: This property will always be equal to the this of the function.

example.desc: Alert that currentTarget matches the `this` keyword.

entry.name: event.relatedTarget
entry.desc: The other DOM element involved in the event, if any.

longdesc.p: For mouseout, indicates the element being entered; for mousein, indicates the element being exited.

example.desc: On mouseout of anchors, alert the element type being entered.

entry.name: event.data
entry.desc: Contains the optional data passed to jQuery.fn.bind when the current executing handler was bound.

example.desc: The description of the example.

entry.name: event.target
entry.desc: The DOM element that initiated the event.

longdesc.p: This can be the element that registered for the event or a child of it. It is often useful to compare event.target to this in order to determine if the event is being handled due to event bubbling. This property is very useful in event delegation, when events bubble.

example.desc: Display the tag's name on click
example.css: span, strong, p { padding: 8px; display: block; border: 1px solid #999; }

example.desc: Implements a simple event delegation: The click handler is added to an unordered list, and the children of its li children are hidden. Clicking one of the li children toggles (see toggle()) their children.

entry.name: event.type
entry.desc: Describes the nature of the event.

example.desc: On all anchor clicks, alert the event type.

entry.name: jQuery.fx.off
entry.desc: Globally disable all animations.

longdesc.p: When this property is set to true, all animation methods will immediately set elements to their final state when called, rather than displaying an effect. This may be desirable for a couple reasons:

ul.li: jQuery is being used on a low-resource device.
Users are encountering accessibility problems with the animations (see the article Turn Off Animation for more information).

longdesc.p: Animations can be turned back on by setting the property to false.

example.desc: Toggle animation on and off
example.css: div { width:50px; height:30px; margin:5px; float:left; background:green; }

category.name: Properties of the Global jQuery Object

entry.name: each

argument.name: function(index, Element)
argument.desc: A function to execute for each matched element.

entry.desc: Iterate over a jQuery object, executing a function for each matched element.

longdesc.p: The .each() method is designed to make DOM looping constructs concise and less error-prone. When called it iterates over the DOM elements that are part of the jQuery object. Each time the callback runs, it is passed the current loop iteration, beginning from 0. More importantly, the callback is fired in the context of the current DOM element, so the keyword this refers to the element.
Suppose we had a simple unordered list on the page:
We can select the list items and iterate across them:
A message is thus alerted for each item in the list:
We can stop the loop from within the callback function by returning false.

example.desc: Iterates over three divs and sets their color property.
example.css: div { color:red; text-align:center; cursor:pointer; font-weight:bolder; width:300px; }

example.desc: If you want to have the jQuery object instead of the regular DOM element, use the $(this) function, for example:
example.html:
To do list: (click here to change)
  • Eat
  • Sleep
  • Be merry

example.desc: You can use 'return' to break out of each() loops early.

entry.name: jQuery.pushStack

argument.name: elements
argument.desc: An array of elements to push onto the stack and make into a new jQuery object.

argument.name: elements
argument.desc: An array of elements to push onto the stack and make into a new jQuery object.

argument.name: name
argument.desc: The name of a jQuery method that generated the array of elements.

argument.name: arguments
argument.desc: The arguments that were passed in to the jQuery method (for serialization).

entry.desc: Add a collection of DOM elements onto the jQuery stack.

example.desc: Add some elements onto the jQuery stack, then pop back off again.

entry.name: jQuery.globalEval

argument.name: code
argument.desc: The JavaScript code to execute.

entry.desc: Execute some JavaScript code globally.

longdesc.p: This method behaves differently from using a normal JavaScript eval() in that it's executed within the global context (which is important for loading external scripts dynamically).

example.desc: Execute a script in the global context.

entry.name: jQuery.isXMLDoc

argument.name: node
argument.desc: The DOM node that will be checked to see if it's in an XML document.

entry.desc: Check to see if a DOM node is within an XML document (or is an XML document).

example.desc: Check an object to see if it's in an XML document.

entry.name: jQuery.removeData

argument.name: element
argument.desc: A DOM element from which to remove data.

argument.name: name
argument.desc: A string naming the piece of data to remove.

entry.desc: Remove a previously-stored piece of data.

longdesc.p: Note: This is a low-level method, you should probably use .removeData() instead.

The jQuery.removeData() method allows us to remove values that were previously set using jQuery.data(). When called with the name of a key, jQuery.removeData() deletes that particular value; when called with no arguments, all values are removed.

example.desc: Set a data store for 2 names then remove one of them.
example.css: div { margin:2px; color:blue; } span { color:red; }
example.html:
value1 before creation:
value1 after creation:
value1 after removal:
value2 after removal:

entry.name: jQuery.data

argument.name: element
argument.desc: The DOM element to associate with the data.

argument.name: key
argument.desc: A string naming the piece of data to set.

argument.name: value
argument.desc: The new data value.

entry.desc: Store arbitrary data associated with the specified element.

longdesc.p: Note: This is a low-level method; you should probably use .data() instead.

The jQuery.data() method allows us to attach data of any type to DOM elements in a way that is safe from circular references and therefore from memory leaks. We can set several distinct values for a single element and retrieve them later:

example.desc: Store then retrieve a value from the div element.
example.css: div { color:blue; } span { color:red; }

entry.name: jQuery.data

argument.name: element
argument.desc: The DOM element to query for the data.

argument.name: key
argument.desc: Name of the data stored.

argument.name: element
argument.desc: The DOM element to query for the data.

entry.desc: Returns value at named data store for the element, as set by jQuery.data(element, name, value), or the full data store for the element.

longdesc.p: Note: This is a low-level method; you should probably use .data() instead.

The jQuery.data() method allows us to attach data of any type to DOM elements in a way that is safe from circular references and therefore from memory leaks. We can retrieve several distinct values for a single element one at a time, or as a set:
The above lines alert the data values that were set on the body element. If nothing was set on that element, an empty string is returned.

Calling jQuery.data(element) retrieves all of the element's associated values as a JavaScript object. Note that jQuery itself uses this method to store data for internal use, such as event handlers, so do not assume that it contains only data that your own code has stored.

example.desc: Get the data named "blah" stored at for an element.
example.html:
A div

The "blah" value of this div is ?

entry.name: jQuery.dequeue

argument.name: element
argument.desc: A DOM element from which to remove and execute a queued function.

argument.name: queueName
argument.desc: A string containing the name of the queue. Defaults to fx, the standard effects queue.

entry.desc: Execute the next function on the queue for the matched element.

longdesc.p: Note: This is a low-level method, you should probably use .dequeue() instead.

When jQuery.dequeue() is called, the next function on the queue is removed from the queue, and then executed. This function should in turn (directly or indirectly) cause jQuery.dequeue() to be called, so that the sequence can continue.

example.desc: Use dequeue to end a custom queue function which allows the queue to keep going.

entry.name: jQuery.queue

argument.name: element
argument.desc: A DOM element to inspect for an attached queue.

argument.name: queueName
argument.desc: A string containing the name of the queue. Defaults to fx, the standard effects queue.

entry.desc: Show the queue of functions to be executed on the matched element.

longdesc.p: Note: This is a low-level method, you should probably use .queue() instead.

example.desc: Show the length of the queue.

entry.name: jQuery.queue

argument.name: element
argument.desc: A DOM element where the array of queued functions is attached.

argument.name: queueName
argument.desc: A string containing the name of the queue. Defaults to fx, the standard effects queue.

argument.name: newQueue
argument.desc: An array of functions to replace the current queue contents.

argument.name: element
argument.desc: A DOM element on which to add a queued function.

argument.name: queueName
argument.desc: A string containing the name of the queue. Defaults to fx, the standard effects queue.

argument.name: callback()
argument.desc: The new function to add to the queue.

entry.desc: Manipulate the queue of functions to be executed on the matched element.

longdesc.p: Note: This is a low-level method, you should probably use .queue() instead.

Every element can have one or more queues of functions attached to it by jQuery. In most applications, only one queue (called fx) is used. Queues allow a sequence of actions to be called on an element asynchronously, without halting program execution.

The jQuery.queue() method allows us to directly manipulate this queue of functions. Calling jQuery.queue() with a callback is particularly useful; it allows us to place a new function at the end of the queue.
Note that when adding a function with jQuery.queue(), we should ensure that jQuery.dequeue() is eventually called so that the next function in line executes.

example.desc: Queue a custom function.
Set a queue array to delete the queue.

entry.name: clearQueue

argument.name: queueName
argument.desc: A string containing the name of the queue. Defaults to fx, the standard effects queue.

entry.desc: Remove from the queue all items that have not yet been run.

longdesc.p: When the .clearQueue() method is called, all functions on the queue that have not been executed are removed from the queue. When used without an argument, .clearQueue() removes the remaining functions from fx, the standard effects queue. In this way it is similar to .stop(true). However, while the .stop() method is meant to be used only with animations, .clearQueue() can also be used to remove any function that has been added to a generic jQuery queue with the .queue() method.

example.desc: Empty the queue.

entry.name: toArray
entry.desc: Retrieve all the DOM elements contained in the jQuery set, as an array.

longdesc.p: .toArray() returns all of the elements in the jQuery set:
All of the matched DOM nodes are returned by this call, contained in a standard array:

example.desc: Selects all divs in the document and returns the DOM Elements as an Array, then uses the built-in reverse-method to reverse that array.
example.css: span { color:red; }

entry.name: jQuery.isEmptyObject

argument.name: object
argument.desc: The object that will be checked to see if it's empty.

entry.desc: Check to see if an object is empty (contains no properties).

longdesc.p: As of jQuery 1.4 this method checks both properties on the object itself and properties inherited from prototypes (in that it doesn't use hasOwnProperty).

example.desc: Check an object to see if it's empty.

entry.name: jQuery.isPlainObject

argument.name: object
argument.desc: The object that will be checked to see if it's a plain object.

entry.desc: Check to see if an object is a plain object (created using "{}" or "new Object").

example.desc: Check an object to see if it's a plain object.

entry.name: keydown

argument.name: handler(eventObject)
argument.desc: A function to execute each time the event is triggered.

entry.desc: Bind an event handler to the "keydown" JavaScript event, or trigger that event on an element.

longdesc.p: This method is a shortcut for .bind('keydown', handler) in the first variation, and .trigger('keydown') in the second.

The keydown event is sent to an element when the user first presses a key on the keyboard. It can be attached to any element, but the event is only sent to the element that has the focus. Focusable elements can vary between browsers, but form elements can always get focus so are reasonable candidates for this event type.
For example, consider the HTML:
longdesc.pre: Trigger the handler
longdesc.p: The event handler can be bound to the input field:
Now when the insertion point is inside the field and a key is pressed, the alert is displayed:
We can trigger the event manually when another element is clicked:
After this code executes, clicks on Trigger the handler will also alert the message.

If key presses anywhere need to be caught (for example, to implement global shortcut keys on a page), it is useful to attach this behavior to the document object. Because of event bubbling, all key presses will make their way up the DOM to the document object unless explicitly stopped.

To determine which key was pressed, we can examine the event object that is passed to the handler function. While browsers use differing properties to store this information, jQuery normalizes the .which property so we can reliably use it to retrieve the key code. This code corresponds to a key on the keyboard, including codes for special keys such as arrows. For catching actual text entry, .keypress() may be a better choice.

example.desc: Show the event object for the keydown handler when a key is pressed in the input.
example.html: <form> <fieldset> <label for="target">Type Something:</label> <input id="target" type="text" /> </fieldset> </form> <button id="other"> Trigger the handler </button> <script type="text/javascript" src="/scripts/events.js"></script>

entry.name: index

argument.name: selector
argument.desc: A selector representing a jQuery collection in which to look for an element.

argument.name: element
argument.desc: The DOM element or first element within the jQuery object to look for.

entry.desc: Search for a given element from among the matched elements.

longdesc.p: If no argument is passed to the .index() method, the return value is an integer indicating the position of the first element within the jQuery object relative to its sibling elements.

If .index() is called on a collection of elements and a DOM element or jQuery object is passed in, .index() returns an integer indicating the position of the passed element relative to the original collection.

If a selector string is passed as an argument, .index() returns an integer indicating the position of the original element relative to the elements matched by the selector. If the element is not found, .index() will return -1.
The complementary operation to .get(), which accepts an index and returns a DOM node, .index() can take a DOM node and returns an index. Suppose we have a simple unordered list on the page:
If we retrieve one of the three list items (for example, through a DOM function or as the context to an event handler), .index() can search for this list item within the set of matched elements:
Similarly, if we retrieve a jQuery object consisting of one of the three list items, .index() will search for that list item:
We get back the zero-based position of the list item:
Note that if the jQuery collection used as the .index() method's argument contains more than one element, the first element within the matched set of elements will be used.
We get back the zero-based position of the first list item within the matched set:
If we use a string as the .index() method's argument, it is interpreted as a jQuery selector string. The first element among the object's matched elements which also matches this selector is located.
We get back the zero-based position of the list item:
If we omit the argument, .index() will return the position of the first element within the set of matched elements in relation to its siblings:
Again, we get back the zero-based position of the list item:

example.desc: On click, returns the index (based zero) of that div in the page.
example.css: div { background:yellow; margin:5px; } span { color:red; }

example.desc: Returns the index for the element with ID bar.
example.css: div { font-weight: bold; color: #090; }

example.desc: Returns the index for the first item in the jQuery collection.
example.css: div { font-weight: bold; color: #090; }

example.desc: Returns the index for the element with ID bar in relation to all <li> elements.
example.css: div { font-weight: bold; color: #090; }

example.desc: Returns the index for the element with ID bar in relation to its siblings.
example.css: div { font-weight: bold; color: #090; }

example.desc: Returns -1, as there is no element with ID foobar.
example.css: div { font-weight: bold; color: #090; }

entry.name: removeData

argument.name: name
argument.desc: A string naming the piece of data to delete.

entry.desc: Remove a previously-stored piece of data.

longdesc.p: The .removeData() method allows us to remove values that were previously set using .data(). When called with the name of a key, .removeData() deletes that particular value; when called with no arguments, all values are removed.

example.desc: Set a data store for 2 names then remove one of them.
example.css: div { margin:2px; color:blue; } span { color:red; }

value1 after creation:
value1 after removal:
value2 after removal:

entry.name: data

argument.name: key
argument.desc: A string naming the piece of data to set.

argument.name: value
argument.desc: The new data value; it can be any Javascript type including Array or Object.

argument.name: obj
argument.desc: An object of key-value pairs of data to set.

entry.desc: Store arbitrary data associated with the matched elements.

longdesc.p: The .data() method allows us to attach data of any type to DOM elements in a way that is safe from circular references and therefore from memory leaks.
We can set several distinct values for a single element and retrieve them later:
Note: Setting an element's data object with .data(obj) replaces all data previously stored with that element, including events that have been bound to the element.

example.desc: Store then retrieve a value from the div element.
example.css: div { color:blue; } span { color:red; }

argument.name: key
argument.desc: Name of the data stored.

longdesc.p: The .data() method allows us to attach data of any type to DOM elements in a way that is safe from circular references and therefore from memory leaks. We can retrieve several distinct values for a single element one at a time, or as a set:
The above lines alert the data values that were set on the body element. If nothing was set on that element, an empty string is returned:
Calling .data() with no parameters retrieves all of the values as a JavaScript object.

entry.name: get

argument.name: index
argument.desc: A zero-based integer indicating which element to retrieve.

entry.desc: Retrieve the DOM elements matched by the jQuery object.

longdesc.p: The .get() method grants us access to the DOM nodes underlying each jQuery object. Suppose we had a simple unordered list on the page:
Without a parameter, .get() returns all of the elements:
All of the matched DOM nodes are returned by this call, contained in a standard array:
With an index specified, .get() will retrieve a single element:
Since the index is zero-based, the first list item is returned:
Each jQuery object also masquerades as an array, so we can use the array dereferencing operator to get at the list item instead:
However, this syntax lacks some of the additional capabilities of .get(), such as specifying a negative index:
A negative index is counted from the end of the matched set, so this example will return the last item in the list:

entry.name: jQuery.noConflict

argument.name: removeAll
argument.desc: A Boolean indicating whether to remove all jQuery variables from the global scope (including jQuery itself).

entry.desc: Relinquish jQuery's control of the $ variable.

longdesc.p: Many JavaScript libraries use $ as a function or variable name, just as jQuery does. In jQuery's case, $ is just an alias for jQuery, so all functionality is available without using $. If we need to use another JavaScript library alongside jQuery, we can return control of $ back to the other library with a call to $.noConflict():
longdesc.pre:
<script type="text/javascript" src="other_lib.js"></script>
<script type="text/javascript" src="jquery.js"></script>
<script type="text/javascript">
  $.noConflict();
  // Code that uses other library's $ can follow here.
</script>
longdesc.p: This technique is especially effective in conjunction with the .ready() method's ability to alias the jQuery object, as within callback passed to .ready() we can use $ if we wish without fear of conflicts later:
longdesc.pre:
<script type="text/javascript" src="other_lib.js"></script>
<script type="text/javascript" src="jquery.js"></script>
<script type="text/javascript">
  $.noConflict();
  jQuery(document).ready(function($) {
    // Code that uses jQuery's $ can follow here.
  });
  // Code that uses other library's $ can follow here.
</script>
longdesc.p: If necessary, we can free up the jQuery name as well by passing true as an argument to the method. This is rarely necessary, and if we must do this (for example, if we need to use multiple versions of the jQuery library on the same page), we need to consider that most plug-ins rely on the presence of the jQuery variable and may not operate correctly in this situation.

example.desc: Maps the original object that was referenced by $ back to $.

Reverts the $ alias and then creates and executes a function to provide the $ as a jQuery alias inside the functions scope. Inside the function the original $ object is not available. This works well for most plugins that don't rely on any other library.
You can chain the jQuery.noConflict() with the shorthand ready for a compact code.
Creates a different alias instead of jQuery to use in the rest of the script.
Completely move jQuery to a new namespace in another object.

entry.name: selected
entry.desc: Selects all elements that are selected.

longdesc.p: The :selected selector works for <option> elements. It does not work for checkboxes or radio inputs; use :checked for them.

example.desc: Attaches a change event to the select that gets the text for each selected option and writes them in the div. It then triggers the event for the initial text draw.
example.css: div { color:red; }

entry.name: checked
entry.desc: Matches all elements that are checked.

longdesc.p: The :checked selector works for checkboxes and radio buttons. For select elements, use the :selected selector.

example.desc: Finds all input elements that are checked.
example.css: div { color:red; }
example.results: <input type="checkbox" name="newsletter" checked="checked" value="Daily" />, <input type="checkbox" name="newsletter" checked="checked" value="Monthly" /> ]

entry.name: disabled
entry.desc: Selects all elements that are disabled.

longdesc.p: As with other pseudo-class selectors (those that begin with a ":") it is recommended to precede it with a tag name or some other selector; otherwise, the universal selector ("*") is implied. In other words, the bare $(':disabled') is equivalent to $('*:disabled'), so $('input:disabled') should be used instead.

example.desc: Finds all input elements that are disabled.

entry.name: enabled
entry.desc: Selects all elements that are enabled.

longdesc.p: As with other pseudo-class selectors (those that begin with a ":") it is recommended to precede it with a tag name or some other selector; otherwise, the universal selector ("*") is implied. In other words, the bare $(':enabled') is equivalent to $('*:enabled'), so $('input:enabled') should be used instead.

example.desc: Finds all input elements that are enabled.

entry.name: checkbox
entry.desc: Selects all elements of type checkbox.

longdesc.p: $(':checkbox') is equivalent to $('[type=checkbox]'). As with other pseudo-class selectors (those that begin with a ":") it is recommended to precede it with a tag name or some other selector; otherwise, the universal selector ("*") is implied. In other words, the bare $(':checkbox') is equivalent to $('*:checkbox'), so $('input:checkbox') should be used instead.

example.desc: Finds all checkbox inputs.
example.css: textarea { height:25px; }

entry.name: radio
entry.desc: Selects all elements of type radio.

longdesc.p: $(':radio') is equivalent to $('[type=radio]'). As with other pseudo-class selectors (those that begin with a ":") it is recommended to precede it with a tag name or some other selector; otherwise, the universal selector ("*") is implied. In other words, the bare $(':radio') is equivalent to $('*:radio'), so $('input:radio') should be used instead.
To select a set of associated radio buttons, you might use: $('input[name=gender]:radio')

example.desc: Finds all radio inputs.
example.css: textarea { height:25px; }

entry.name: password
entry.desc: Selects all elements of type password.

longdesc.p: $(':password') is equivalent to $('[type=password]'). As with other pseudo-class selectors (those that begin with a ":") it is recommended to precede it with a tag name or some other selector; otherwise, the universal selector ("*") is implied. In other words, the bare $(':password') is equivalent to $('*:password'), so $('input:password') should be used instead.

example.desc: Finds all password inputs.

entry.name: text
entry.desc: Selects all elements of type text.

longdesc.p: $(':text') is equivalent to $('[type=text]') and thus selects all <input type="text"> elements. As with other pseudo-class selectors (those that begin with a ":") it is recommended to precede it with a tag name or some other selector; otherwise, the universal selector ("*") is implied. In other words, the bare $(':text') is equivalent to $('*:text'), so $('input:text') should be used instead.

example.desc: Finds all text inputs.
example.css: textarea { height:25px; }

entry.name: input
entry.desc: Selects all input, textarea, select and button elements.

longdesc.p: The :input selector basically selects all form controls.

entry.name: only-child
entry.desc: Selects all elements that are the only child of their parent.

longdesc.p: If the parent has other child elements, nothing is matched.

example.desc: Finds the button with no siblings in each matched div and modifies look.
example.css: div { width:100px; height:80px; margin:5px; float:left; background:#b9e }

entry.name: last-child
entry.desc: Selects all elements that are the last child of their parent.

longdesc.p: While :last matches only a single element, :last-child can match more than one: one for each parent.

example.desc: Finds the last span in each matched div and adds some css plus a hover state.
example.css: span.solast { text-decoration:line-through; }

entry.name: first-child
entry.desc: Selects all elements that are the first child of their parent.

longdesc.p: While :first matches only a single element, the :first-child selector can match more than one: one for each parent. This is equivalent to :nth-child(1).

example.desc: Finds the first span in each matched div to underline and add a hover state.
example.css: span { color:#008; } span.sogreen { color:green; font-weight: bolder; }

entry.name: nth-child

argument.name: index
argument.desc: The index of each child to match, starting with 1, the string even or odd, or an equation ( eg. :nth-child(even), :nth-child(4n) )

entry.desc: Selects all elements that are the nth-child of their parent.

longdesc.p: Because jQuery's implementation of :nth-child(n) is strictly derived from the CSS specification, the value of n is "1-indexed", meaning that the counting starts at 1. For all other selector expressions, however, jQuery follows JavaScript's "0-indexed" counting. Therefore, given a single <ul> containing two <li>s, $('li:nth-child(1)') selects the first <li> while $('li:eq(1)') selects the second.

The :nth-child(n) pseudo-class is easily confused with :eq(n), even though the two can result in dramatically different matched elements. With :nth-child(n), all children are counted, regardless of what they are, and the specified element is selected only if it matches the selector attached to the pseudo-class. With :eq(n) only the selector attached to the pseudo-class is counted, not limited to children of any other element, and the nth one is selected.
Further discussion of this unusual usage can be found in the W3C CSS specification.

example.desc: Finds the second li in each matched ul and notes it.
example.css: div { float:left; } span { color:blue; }

example.desc: This is a playground to see how the selector works with different strings. Notice that this is different from the :even and :odd which have no regard for parent and just filter the list of elements to every other one. The :nth-child, however, counts the index of the child to its particular parent. In any case, it's easier to see than explain so...

entry.name: attributeContainsWord

argument.name: attribute
argument.desc: An attribute name.

argument.name: value
argument.desc: An attribute value. Quotes are optional.

entry.desc: Selects elements that have the specified attribute with a value containing a given word, delimited by spaces.

longdesc.p: This selector matches the test string against each word in the attribute value, where a "word" is defined as a string delimited by whitespace. The selector matches if the test string is exactly equal to any of the words.

entry.name: attributeContains

argument.name: attribute
argument.desc: An attribute name.

argument.name: value
argument.desc: An attribute value. Quotes are optional.

entry.desc: Selects elements that have the specified attribute with a value containing the a given substring.

longdesc.p: This is the most generous of the jQuery attribute selectors that match against a value. It will select an element if the selector's string appears anywhere within the element's attribute value. Compare this selector with the Attribute Contains Word selector (e.g. [attr~=word]), which is more appropriate in many cases.

example.desc: Finds all inputs with a name attribute that contains 'man' and sets the value with some text.

entry.name: attributeEndsWith

argument.name: attribute
argument.desc: An attribute name.

argument.name: value
argument.desc: An attribute value. Quotes are optional.

entry.desc: Selects elements that have the specified attribute with a value ending exactly with a given string.

example.desc: Finds all inputs with an attribute name that ends with 'letter' and puts text in them.

entry.name: attributeStartsWith

argument.name: attribute
argument.desc: An attribute name.

argument.name: value
argument.desc: An attribute value. Quotes are optional.

entry.desc: Selects elements that have the specified attribute with a value beginning exactly with a given string.

longdesc.p: This selector can be useful for identifying elements in pages produced by server-side frameworks that produce HTML with systematic element IDs. However it will be slower than using a class selector so leverage classes, if you can, to group like elements.

entry.name: visible
entry.desc: Selects all elements that are visible.

longdesc.p: Elements can be considered hidden for several reasons:

ul.li: They have a display value of none.
They are form elements with type="hidden".
Their width and height are explicitly set to 0.
An ancestor element is hidden, so the element is not shown on the page.

longdesc.p: How :visible is calculated was changed in jQuery 1.3.2. The release notes outline the changes in more detail.

example.desc: Make all visible divs turn yellow on click.
example.css: div { width:50px; height:40px; margin:5px; border:3px outset green; float:left; } .starthidden { display:none; }

entry.name: hidden
entry.desc: Selects all elements that are hidden.

longdesc.p: Elements can be considered hidden for several reasons:

ul.li: They have a display value of none.
They are form elements with type="hidden".
Their width and height are explicitly set to 0.
An ancestor element is hidden, so the element is not shown on the page.

longdesc.p: How :hidden is determined was changed in jQuery 1.3.2. An element is assumed to be hidden if it or any of its parents consumes no space in the document. CSS visibility isn't taken into account (therefore $(elem).css('visibility','hidden').is(':hidden') == false). The release notes outline the changes in more detail.

example.desc: Shows all hidden divs and counts hidden inputs.

entry.name: parent
entry.desc: Select all elements that are the parent of another element, including text nodes.

longdesc.p: This is the inverse of :empty.
One important thing to note regarding the use of :parent (and :empty) is that child elements include text nodes.

The W3C recommends that the

element have at least one child node, even if that child is merely text (see http://www.w3.org/TR/html401/struct/text.html#edef-P). Some other elements, on the other hand, are empty (i.e. have no children) by definition: , ,
, and

, for example.

example.desc: Finds all tds with children, including text.
example.css: td { width:40px; background:green; }

entry.name: has
entry.desc: Selects elements which contain at least one element that matches the specified selector.

longdesc.p:
The expression $('div:has(p)') matches a
if a

exists anywhere among its descendants, not just as a direct child.

argument.name: selector
argument.desc: Any selector.

example.html:
Hello in a paragraph

Hello again! (with no paragraph)

entry.name: empty
entry.desc: Select all elements that have no children (including text nodes).

longdesc.p: This is the inverse of :parent.
One important thing to note with :empty (and :parent) is that child elements include text nodes.

The W3C recommends that the

element have at least one child node, even if that child is merely text (see http://www.w3.org/TR/html401/struct/text.html#edef-P). Some other elements, on the other hand, are empty (i.e. have no children) by definition: , ,
, and

, for example.

entry.name: contains
entry.desc: Select all elements that contain the specified text.

longdesc.p: The matching text can appear directly within the selected element, in any of that element's descendants, or a combination thereof. As with attribute value selectors, text inside the parentheses of :contains() can be written as bare words or surrounded by quotation marks. The text must have matching case to be selected.

argument.name: text
argument.desc: A string of text to look for. It's case sensitive.

example.desc: Finds all divs containing "John" and underlines them.

entry.name: animated
entry.desc: Select all elements that are in the progress of an animation at the time the selector is run.

example.desc: Change the color of any div that is animated.
example.css: div { background:yellow; border:1px solid #AAA; width:80px; height:80px; margin:5px; float:left; } div.colored { background:green; }

entry.name: header
entry.desc: Selects all elements that are headers, like h1, h2, h3 and so on.

example.desc: Adds a background and text color to all the headers on the page.
example.css: body { font-size: 10px; font-family: Arial; } h1, h2 { margin: 3px 0; }

entry.name: lt

argument.name: index
argument.desc: Zero-based index.

entry.desc: Select all elements at an index less than index within the matched set.

longdesc.p: The index-related selectors (including this "less than" selector) filter the set of elements that have matched the expressions that precede them. They narrow the set down based on the order of the elements within this matched set. For example, if elements are first selected with a class selector (.myclass) and four elements are returned, these elements are given indices 0 through 3 for the purposes of these selectors.

Note that since JavaScript arrays use 0-based indexing, these selectors reflect that fact. This is why $('.myclass:lt(1)') selects the first element in the document with the class myclass, rather than selecting no elements. In contrast, :nth-child(n) uses 1-based indexing to conform to the CSS specification.

example.desc: Finds TDs less than the one with the 4th index (TD#4).

entry.name: gt
entry.desc: Select all elements at an index greater than index within the matched set.

longdesc.p: The index-related selector expressions (including this "greater than" selector) filter the set of elements that have matched the expressions that precede them. They narrow the set down based on the order of the elements within this matched set. For example, if elements are first selected with a class selector (.myclass) and four elements are returned, these elements are given indices 0 through 3 for the purposes of these selectors.

Note that since JavaScript arrays use 0-based indexing, these selectors reflect that fact. This is why $('.myclass:gt(1)') selects elements after the second element in the document with the class myclass, rather than after the first. In contrast, :nth-child(n) uses 1-based indexing to conform to the CSS specification.

argument.name: index
argument.desc: Zero-based index.

example.desc: Finds TD #5 and higher. Reminder: the indexing starts at 0.

entry.name: eq

argument.name: index
argument.desc: Zero-based index of the element to match.

entry.desc: Select the element at index n within the matched set.

longdesc.p: The index-related selectors (:eq(), :lt(), :gt(), :even, :odd) filter the set of elements that have matched the expressions that precede them. They narrow the set down based on the order of the elements within this matched set. For example, if elements are first selected with a class selector (.myclass) and four elements are returned, these elements are given indices 0 through 3 for the purposes of these selectors.

Note that since JavaScript arrays use 0-based indexing, these selectors reflect that fact. This is why $('.myclass:eq(1)') selects the second element in the document with the class myclass, rather than the first. In contrast, :nth-child(n) uses 1-based indexing to conform to the CSS specification.

example.desc: Finds the third td.

entry.name: odd
entry.desc: Selects odd elements, zero-indexed. See also even.

longdesc.p: In particular, note that the 0-based indexing means that, counter-intuitively, :odd selects the second element, fourth element, and so on within the matched set.

example.desc: Finds odd table rows, matching the second, fourth and so on (index 1, 3, 5 etc.).
example.html:
Row with Index #0
Row with Index #1
Row with Index #2
Row with Index #3

entry.name: even
entry.desc: Selects even elements, zero-indexed. See also odd.

longdesc.p: In particular, note that the 0-based indexing means that, counter-intuitively, :even selects the first element, third element, and so on within the matched set.

example.desc: Finds even table rows, matching the first, third and so on (index 0, 2, 4 etc.).
example.html:
Row with Index #0
Row with Index #1

entry.desc: Selects all elements that do not match the given selector.

entry.desc: Selects the last matched element.

longdesc.p: Note that :last selects a single element by filtering the current jQuery collection and matching the last element within it.

entry.name: first
entry.desc: Selects the first matched element.

longdesc.p: The :first pseudo-class is equivalent to :eq(0). It could also be written as :lt(1). While this matches only a single element, :first-child can match more than one: One for each parent.

entry.name: next siblings

argument.name: prev
argument.desc: Any valid selector.

argument.name: siblings
argument.desc: A selector to filter elements that are the following siblings of the first selector.

entry.desc: Selects all sibling elements that follow after the "prev" element, have the same parent, and match the filtering "siblings" selector.

longdesc.p: The notable difference between (prev + next) and (prev ~ siblings) is their respective reach. While the former reaches only to the immediately following sibling element, the latter extends that reach to all following sibling elements.

example.desc: Finds all divs that are siblings after the element with #prev as its id. Notice the span isn't selected since it is not a div and the "niece" isn't selected since it is a child of a sibling, not an actual sibling.

entry.name: next adjacent

argument.name: prev
argument.desc: Any valid selector.

argument.name: next
argument.desc: A selector to match the element that is next to the first selector.

entry.desc: Selects all next elements matching "next" that are immediately preceded by a sibling "prev".

longdesc.p: One important point to consider with both the next adjacent sibling selector (prev + next) and the general sibling selector (prev ~ siblings) is that the elements on either side of the combinator must share the same parent.

example.desc: Finds all inputs that are next to a label.

entry.name: child

argument.name: parent
argument.desc: Any valid selector.

argument.name: child
argument.desc: A selector to filter the child elements.

entry.desc: Selects all direct child elements specified by "child" of elements specified by "parent".

longdesc.p: As a CSS selector, the child combinator is supported by all modern web browsers including Safari, Firefox, Opera, Chrome, and Internet Explorer 7 and above, but notably not by Internet Explorer versions 6 and below. However, in jQuery, this selector (along with all others) works across all supported browsers, including IE6.
The child combinator (E > F) can be thought of as a more specific form of the descendant combinator (E F) in that it selects only first-level descendants.

example.desc: Places a border around all list items that are children of <ul class="topnav"> .
example.css: body { font-size:14px; }

argument.desc: A selector to filter the descendant elements.

entry.desc: Selects all elements that are descendants of a given ancestor.

longdesc.p: A descendant of an element could be a child, grandchild, great-grandchild, and so on, of that element.

The order of the DOM elements in the returned jQuery object may not be identical, as they will be in document order. An alternative to this combinator is the .add() method.

entry.name: element

argument.name: element
argument.desc: An element to search for. Refers to the tagName of DOM nodes.

entry.desc: Selects all elements with the given tag name.

longdesc.p: JavaScript's getElementsByTagName() function is called to return the appropriate elements when this expression is used.

entry.name: id

argument.name: id
argument.desc: An ID to search for, specified via the id attribute of an element.

entry.desc: Selects a single element with the given id attribute.

longdesc.p: For id selectors, jQuery uses the JavaScript function document.getElementById(), which is extremely efficient. When another selector is attached to the id selector, such as h2#pageTitle, jQuery performs an additional check before identifying the element as a match.

Each id value must be used only once within a document. If more than one element has been assigned the same ID, queries that use that ID will only select the first matched element in the DOM. This behavior should not be relied on, however; a document with more than one element using the same ID is invalid.
If the id contains characters like periods or colons you have to escape those characters with backslashes.

blockquote.p: As always, remember that as a developer, your time is typically the most valuable resource. Do not focus on optimization of selector speed unless it is clear that performance needs to be improved.

The scroll event is sent to an element when the user scrolls to a different place in the element. It applies to window objects, but also to scrollable frames and elements with the overflow CSS property set to scroll (or auto when the element's explicit height is less than the height of its contents).

entry.name: resize
entry.desc: Bind an event handler to the "resize" JavaScript event, or trigger that event on an element.

argument.name: handler(eventObject)
argument.desc: A function to execute each time the event is triggered.

longdesc.p: This method is a shortcut for .bind('resize', handler) in the first variation, and .trigger('resize') in the second.
The resize event is sent to the window element when the size of the browser window changes:
Now whenever the browser window's size is changed, the message is appended to <div id="log"> one or more times, depending on the browser.

Code in a resize handler should never rely on the number of times the handler is called. Depending on implementation, resize events can be sent continuously as the resizing is in progress (the typical behavior in Internet Explorer and WebKit-based browsers such as Safari and Chrome), or only once at the end of the resize operation (the typical behavior in Firefox).

entry.name: dequeue

argument.name: queueName
argument.desc: A string containing the name of the queue. Defaults to fx, the standard effects queue.

entry.desc: Execute the next function on the queue for the matched elements.

longdesc.p: When .dequeue() is called, the next function on the queue is removed from the queue, and then executed. This function should in turn (directly or indirectly) cause .dequeue() to be called, so that the sequence can continue.

example.desc: Use dequeue to end a custom queue function which allows the queue to keep going.

entry.name: queue

argument.name: queueName
argument.desc: A string containing the name of the queue. Defaults to fx, the standard effects queue.

entry.desc: Show the queue of functions to be executed on the matched elements.

example.desc: Show the length of the queue.

entry.name: queue

argument.name: queueName
argument.desc: A string containing the name of the queue. Defaults to fx, the standard effects queue.

argument.name: newQueue
argument.desc: An array of functions to replace the current queue contents.

argument.name: queueName
argument.desc: A string containing the name of the queue. Defaults to fx, the standard effects queue.

argument.name: callback( next )
argument.desc: The new function to add to the queue, with a function to call that will dequeue the next item.

entry.desc: Manipulate the queue of functions to be executed on the matched elements.

longdesc.p: Every element can have one to many queues of functions attached to it by jQuery. In most applications, only one queue (called fx) is used. Queues allow a sequence of actions to be called on an element asynchronously, without halting program execution. The typical example of this is calling multiple animation methods on an element. For example:
When this statement is executed, the element begins its sliding animation immediately, but the fading transition is placed on the fx queue to be called only once the sliding transition is complete.
The .queue() method allows us to directly manipulate this queue of functions. Calling .queue() with a callback is particularly useful; it allows us to place a new function at the end of the queue.
This feature is similar to providing a callback function with an animation method, but does not require the callback to be given at the time the animation is performed.
This is equivalent to:
Note that when adding a function with .queue(), we should ensure that .dequeue() is eventually called so that the next function in line executes.

In jQuery 1.4 the function that's called is passed in another function, as the first argument, that when called automatically dequeues the next item and keeps the queue moving. You would use it like so:

entry.name: keyup
entry.desc: Bind an event handler to the "keyup" JavaScript event, or trigger that event on an element.

argument.name: handler(eventObject)
argument.desc: A function to execute each time the event is triggered.

longdesc.p: This method is a shortcut for .bind('keyup', handler) in the first variation, and .trigger('keyup') in the second.

The keyup event is sent to an element when the user releases a key on the keyboard. It can be attached to any element, but the event is only sent to the element that has the focus. Focusable elements can vary between browsers, but form elements can always get focus so are reasonable candidates for this event type.
For example, consider the HTML:
longdesc.pre: Trigger the handler
longdesc.p: The event handler can be bound to the input field:
Now when the insertion point is inside the field and a key is pressed and released, the alert is displayed:
We can trigger the event manually when another element is clicked:
After this code executes, clicks on Trigger the handler will also alert the message.

If key presses anywhere need to be caught (for example, to implement global shortcut keys on a page), it is useful to attach this behavior to the document object. Because of event bubbling, all key presses will make their way up the DOM to the document object unless explicitly stopped.

To determine which key was pressed, we can examine the event object that is passed to the handler function. While browsers use differing attributes to store this information, jQuery normalizes the .which attribute so we can reliably use it to retrieve the key code. This code corresponds to a key on the keyboard, including codes for special keys such as arrows. For catching actual text entry, .keypress() may be a better choice.

example.desc: Show the event object for the keyup handler when a key is released in the input.
example.html: <form> <fieldset> <label for="target">Type Something:</label> <input id="target" type="text" /> </fieldset> </form> <button id="other"> Trigger the handler </button> <script type="text/javascript" src="/scripts/events.js"></script>

entry.name: keypress
entry.desc: Bind an event handler to the "keypress" JavaScript event, or trigger that event on an element.

argument.name: handler(eventObject)
argument.desc: A function to execute each time the event is triggered.

longdesc.p: This method is a shortcut for .bind('keypress', handler) in the first variation, and .trigger('keypress') in the second.

The keypress event is sent to an element when the browser registers keyboard input. This is similar to the keydown event, except in the case of key repeats. If the user presses and holds a key, a keydown event is triggered once, but separate keypress events are triggered for each inserted character. In addition, modifier keys (such as Shift) cause keydown events but not keypress events.

A keypress event handler can be attached to any element, but the event is only sent to the element that has the focus. Focusable elements can vary between browsers, but form elements can always get focus so are reasonable candidates for this event type.
For example, consider the HTML:
longdesc.pre: Trigger the handler
longdesc.p: The event handler can be bound to the input field:
Now when the insertion point is inside the field and a key is pressed, the alert is displayed:
The message repeats if the key is held down. We can trigger the event manually when another element is clicked:
After this code executes, clicks on Trigger the handler will also alert the message.

If key presses anywhere need to be caught (for example, to implement global shortcut keys on a page), it is useful to attach this behavior to the document object. Because of event bubbling, all key presses will make their way up the DOM to the document object unless explicitly stopped.

To determine which character was entered, we can examine the event object that is passed to the handler function. While browsers use differing attributes to store this information, jQuery normalizes the .which attribute so we can reliably use it to retrieve the character code.

Note that keydown and keyup provide a code indicating which key is pressed, while keypress indicates which character was entered. For example, a lowercase "a" will be reported as 65 by keydown and keyup, but as 97 by keypress. An uppercase "A" is reported as 65 by all events. Because of this distinction, when catching special keystrokes such as arrow keys, .keydown() or .keyup() is a better choice.

example.desc: Show the event object for the keypress handler when a key is pressed in the input.
example.html: <form> <fieldset> <label for="target">Type Something:</label> <input id="target" type="text" /> </fieldset> </form> <button id="other"> Trigger the handler </button> <script type="text/javascript" src="/scripts/events.js"></script>

entry.name: submit
entry.desc: Bind an event handler to the "submit" JavaScript event, or trigger that event on an element.

argument.name: handler(eventObject)
argument.desc: A function to execute each time the event is triggered.

longdesc.p: This method is a shortcut for .bind('submit', handler) in the first variation, and .trigger('submit') in the second.

The submit event is sent to an element when the user is attempting to submit a form. It can only be attached to <form> elements. Forms can be submitted either by clicking an explicit <input type="submit">, <input type="image">, or <button type="submit">, or by pressing Enter when certain form element has focus.

blockquote.p: Depending on the browser, the Enter key may only cause a form submission if the form has exactly one text field, or only when there is a submit button present. The interface should not rely on a particular behavior for this key unless the issue is forced by observing the keypress event for presses of the Enter key.

After this code executes, clicks on Trigger the handler will also display the message. In addition, the default submit action on the form will be fired, so the form will be submitted.

The JavaScript submit event does not bubble in Internet Explorer. However, scripts that rely on event delegation with the submit event will work consistently across browsers as of jQuery 1.4, which has normalized the event's behavior.

The select event is sent to an element when the user makes a text selection inside it. This event is limited to <input type="text"> fields and <textarea> boxes.

entry.name: change
entry.desc: Bind an event handler to the "change" JavaScript event, or trigger that event on an element.

argument.name: handler(eventObject)

longdesc.p: This method is a shortcut for .bind('change', handler) in the first variation, and .trigger('change') in the second.

The change event is sent to an element when its value changes. This event is limited to <input type="text"> fields, <textarea> boxes and <select> elements. For select boxes, the event is fired immediately when the user makes a selection with the mouse, but for the other element types the event is deferred until the element loses focus.
For example, consider the HTML:

entry.desc: Bind an event handler to the "blur" JavaScript event, or trigger that event on an element.

argument.name: handler(eventObject)

longdesc.p: This method is a shortcut for .bind('blur', handler) in the first variation, and .trigger('blur') in the second.

The blur event is sent to an element when it loses focus. Originally, this event was only applicable to form elements, such as <input>. In recent browsers, the domain of the event has been extended to include all element types. An element can lose focus via keyboard commands, such as the Tab key, or by mouse clicks elsewhere on the page.

entry.name: focus
entry.desc: Bind an event handler to the "focus" JavaScript event, or trigger that event on an element.

argument.name: handler(eventObject)
argument.desc: A function to execute each time the event is triggered.

ul.li: This method is a shortcut for .bind('focus', handler) in the first variation, and .trigger('focus') in the second.

The focus event is sent to an element when it gains focus. This event is implicitly applicable to a limited set of elements, such as form elements (<input>, <select>, etc.) and links (<a href>). In recent browser versions, the event can be extended to include all element types by explicitly setting the element's tabindex property. An element can gain focus via keyboard commands, such as the Tab key, or by mouse clicks on the element.

Elements with focus are usually highlighted in some way by the browser, for example with a dotted line surrounding the element. The focus is used to determine which element is the first to receive keyboard-related events.

The focus event does not bubble in Internet Explorer. Therefore, scripts that rely on event delegation with the focus event will not work consistently across browsers.

entry.name: mousemove
entry.desc: Bind an event handler to the "mousemove" JavaScript event, or trigger that event on an element.

argument.name: handler(eventObject)
argument.desc: A function to execute each time the event is triggered.

longdesc.p: This method is a shortcut for .bind('mousemove', handler) in the first variation, and .trigger('mousemove') in the second.
The mousemove event is sent to an element when the mouse pointer moves inside the element. Any HTML element can receive this event.
For example, consider the HTML:
longdesc.pre:
Move here
Trigger the handler
longdesc.p: The event handler can be bound to the target:
Now when the mouse pointer moves within the target button, the messages are appended to <div id="log">:
We can also trigger the event when the second button is clicked:
After this code executes, clicks on the Trigger button will also append the message:

When tracking mouse movement, we usually need to know the actual position of the mouse pointer. The event object that is passed to the handler contains some information about the mouse coordinates. Properties such as .clientX, .offsetX, and .pageX are available, but support for them differs between browsers. Fortunately, jQuery normalizes the .pageX and .pageY attributes so that they can be used in all browsers. These attributes provide the X and Y coordinates of the mouse pointer relative to the top-left corner of the page, as illustrated in the example output above.

We need to remember that the mousemove event is triggered whenever the mouse pointer moves, even for a pixel. This means that hundreds of events can be generated over a very small amount of time. If the handler has to do any significant processing, or if multiple handlers for the event exist, this can be a serious performance drain on the browser. It is important, therefore, to optimize mousemove handlers as much as possible, and to unbind them as soon as they are no longer needed.

A common pattern is to bind the mousemove handler from within a mousedown hander, and to unbind it from a corresponding mouseup handler. If implementing this sequence of events, remember that the mouseup event might be sent to a different HTML element than the mousemove event was. To account for this, the mouseup handler should typically be bound to an element high up in the DOM tree, such as <body>.

entry.name: mouseleave
entry.desc: Bind an event handler to be fired when the mouse leaves an element, or trigger that handler on an element.

argument.name: handler(eventObject)
argument.desc: A function to execute each time the event is triggered.

longdesc.p: This method is a shortcut for .bind('mouseleave', handler) in the first variation, and .trigger('mouseleave') in the second.

The mouseleave JavaScript event is proprietary to Internet Explorer. Because of the event's general utility, jQuery simulates this event so that it can be used regardless of browser. This event is sent to an element when the mouse pointer leaves the element. Any HTML element can receive this event.
For example, consider the HTML:

Outer
Inner
Trigger the handler
longdesc.p: The event handler can be bound to any element:
Now when the mouse pointer moves out of the Outer <div>, the message is appended to <div id="log">. We can also trigger the event when another element is clicked:
After this code executes, clicks on Trigger the handler will also append the message.

The mouseleave event differs from mouseout in the way it handles event bubbling. If mouseout were used in this example, then when the mouse pointer moved out of the Inner element, the handler would be triggered. This is usually undesirable behavior. The mouseleave event, on the other hand, only triggers its handler when the mouse leaves the element it is bound to, not a descendant. So in this example, the handler is triggered when the mouse leaves the Outer element, but not the Inner element.
